content: A pretty dependable source. Nothing new here, but it's clear, consumer-friendly, and well-organized (top-line items in this article with links to details). http://consumers.m.delivery.net/w/webView?cid=17992440638&mid=1155425626&pid=847270&vid=13533&ee=ZGVicm9ua2FydEBhbHVtLm1pdC5lZHU_&si=&mv=H&bv=H&oc=H&sc=&k=14tcLQ

Their February article on hand washing has useful details I hadn't seen elsewhere, including the news (to me) that hand sanitizers like Purell are distinctly less effective than hand washing with soap (but better than nothing, of course).

What nobody talks about is the practical difficulty of standing there washing for a full 20 seconds as recommended (often described as "sing Happy Birthday twice through"). Hm, an intervention that's effective but requires patience and a habit change... sounds like a practical challenge, so it's worth reminding each other. So here we are...
Also in the series, information I hadn't seen on specifically why wearing face masks is ineffective unless you're already sick or caring for someone who is.
A co-worker shared with me the guidance she was given on hand-washing: Wash your hands like you just diced a jalapeno and now you have to put your contacts in.
Yeah, that flew around Twitter yesterday :-). But not useful for those of us with no such dicing experience!
